sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: Welcome back. Good to have you with us.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: For many people, two years of COVID travel restrictions spelled the end to any hopes of a holiday abroad.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: But this summer, tourists are flocking back to their favourite destinations.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: And in Greece, authorities are expecting a record-breaking year.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: Tom Bolton reports.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: Despite the loss of the Russian and Ukrainian markets, Greek tourism seems to be heading for a new record year.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: In June, over 900,000 visitors from Britain and Germany Ukrainian markets, Greek tourism seems to be heading for a new record year.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: In June, over 900,000 visitors from Britain and Germany, traditionally the two strongest inbound tourism markets, came to the country.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: Preliminary figures show that over half a million British people chose Greece as their holiday destination.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: Authorities expect one million arrivals in the first week of August alone.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: We've had a 20% increase in air arrivals compared to 2019, which was also a great year. Even cruises increased by 25%. We expect this season we'll inject approximately 20 billion euros into the economy. In 2019, that figure was 18 billion. We have every reason to be optimistic.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: After two years of the COVID-19 pandemic, people are eager to travel.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: But many are hesitating because of chaotic scenes seen at many European airports.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: The head of Greece's national tourism organization says Greek airports are an exception, adding that even in August, there will not be angry passengers and hundreds of stacked suitcases.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: There are no problems at Greek airports.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: We have prepared well and we are ready for the high arrivals of August.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: We didn't cut staff in the past months, we didn't make layoffs.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: I believe that our country can be a positive example for other European countries.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: In 2019, there were over 30 million foreign tourists.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: This year, despite the war in Ukraine and the high cost of travelling, Greece believes it will beat this record.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: Tom Bolton, Euronews.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: We leave you with a no comment now from Rio de Janeiro, where a new exhibition is showcasing the work of Vincent van Gogh in a breathtaking 8K resolution. Thanks for watching Euronews tonight. Obrigada, obrigada. Thank you. Thank you.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: One of the leaders of a separate and co-equal branch of government and the President of the United States can't tell her what to do.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: It's complicated and the Chinese are very clear that they don't want a high level visit from a top American office holder to Taiwan right now. All right some important precisions there from Ray Suarez reporting from Washington for us. Ray thank you. Well new figures released by the US Department of Commerce shows

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: that the country's economy has shrunk by 0.9 percent it marks the second consecutive month of GDP contraction unofficially indicating the start of a recession but the White House has tried to quash recession talk claiming that the economy remains strong in many areas the timing is far from ideal for President Joe Biden, who must now prepare for a difficult midterm election season.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: Almost one million people in the suburbs of Wuhan are back under lockdown today after Chinese authorities confirmed four asymptomatic cases of COVID-19.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: Authorities in the Jiangxia district of the city say that all public transport, entertainment venues, religious gatherings and tourist sites will be closed for three days.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: People in areas considered high or medium risk are banned from leaving their homes.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: Wuhan is believed to be the origin of the global Covid pandemic and the city recorded the first identified cases of the virus.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: Now the planet has hit a damning milestone as the world marks Earth overshoot day much earlier than predicted. Now according to the Global Footprint Network and the Worldwide Fund for Nature, humanity has officially consumed enough natural resources to last a year.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: Glynis Crook has the story now. It's a bit like keeping a budget. On the one hand there's Earth's natural resources such as timber and fish, and on the other hand how quickly we use them up.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: Earth Overshoot Day is the day when we cross the tipping point, when we've used up all the ecological resources that Earth is able to generate in the year.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: Today is that day, and we've reached it earlier than ever before.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: In 1971, it was on the 25th of December.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: And this is the first, I mean the earliest time ever that we have celebrated this.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: Imagine you have a business, a company, and you finish the revenue in July. So your revenue are lower than your expenditure. Will you be worried? I guess you would. So I think it's quite alarming.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: waste the world is effectively living on credit determined by the global footprint network the date remains largely symbolic with few countries using the index in policy making glennis crook euronews well still to come airports might be experiencing chaos right now but still greece

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: is on track to see a record tourist season we'll take you there if only through the TV screen after the break Earlier this week in Brussels for us tonight is our correspondent Shona Murray

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: We can cross over to her now shown a lawmakers where you are They're preparing to go on their summer break So they're going to be leaving that packet of sanctions against Russia on the table But what is the sense there as to whether these sanctions are doing enough?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_11
sentences.sentence: Well, there's a consensus that it'll take at least six months to see the impact of the sanctions.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_11
sentences.sentence: For example, with the oil sanctions not due to start until next year, but other sanctions in relation to the exportation of critical technologies to Russia, particularly impacting the aviation industry, which is not just the commercial aviation industry, but also the military. Those things will take some time, but will do a lot of damage. There's also thousands of, or over a thousand companies that have left Russia. And Russia is the most sanctioned country in the world. So there's a belief that this is definitely the right method, the right way of targeting Vladimir Putin. We saw for example just recently as you mentioned there Helena at the sanctioning on gold another important export for Russia as well. But there is a feeling that it'll take time. But certainly they will do huge amount of damage. And in the meantime what is the sense with regards to European unity on these sanctions the appetite for more. I mean is that expected to last in the meantime, what is the sense with regards to European unity on these sanctions, the appetite for more?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: I mean, is that expected to last in the coming months as we leave the summer transition into autumn and winter?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_11
sentences.sentence: Well, the position is fairly unified, particularly when you see what Vladimir Putin has done this week, once again decreasing by half the gas going into Nord Stream 1 pipeline, knowing that this will trigger an economic jitters, possibly even a recession in Germany, even though there hasn't been any sanctions against gas.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_11
sentences.sentence: We have also seen Vladimir Putin engage in a blockade of really important crops, wheat, that is normally exported to places like North Africa, essentially starving parts of North Africa.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_11
sentences.sentence: So there's a feeling that something has to be done, and Vladimir Putin is engaging in a way that's targeting the world, the global economy, global food security.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_11
sentences.sentence: And so I think that the unity is there from the majority of member states, but of course, Helena, we talk about this all the time, you have Viktor Orban in Hungary, which who has disrupted for the last few months the passage of sanctions for various reasons.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_11
sentences.sentence: Obviously some of them have been legitimate, but in lots of ways they've been politically motivated.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_11
sentences.sentence: He's a supporter of Putin.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_11
sentences.sentence: He is criticized, Vladimir Zelensky.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_11
sentences.sentence: So he obviously is a weak link when it comes to the unity.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_11
sentences.sentence: And then, of course, there are countries that are much more enthusiastic or emphatic about sanctions, like the Baltics, like Poland, which really pushed for the sixth sanctions package, the oil sanctions, which obviously did materialise.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_11
sentences.sentence: But I think there's not, at this point, any appetite for, let's say, a gas sanctions package yet. But I think that the position in Brussels is that they'll still have to keep on moving and keep on targeting Putin they can't stop that now but at the same time of course you have to take their people with them because people are suffering from a cost of living crisis and the sanctions could definitely impact that. Helena. Our correspondent Shona Murray there reporting from Brussels.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: Shona, good to talk to you. Thank you.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: Well, after decades of private ownership on national energy markets,

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: European governments are taking a different approach.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: Many are choosing to nationalise energy companies in a bid to secure enough resources for the winter.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: Christopher Pitchers has the story.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: Russia's war in Ukraine could be a game-changer when it comes to Europe's energy map.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: In France, energy giant EDF is being nationalised.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: In Germany, the government is bailing out Uniper, one of the world's largest gas importers, after suffering a serious reduction in Russian natural gas.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: At the same time, European states are becoming more and more interventionist in their energy markets. We asked experts if this new approach is here to stay.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: It is a pattern that we see all across the European Union, and it is going to probably deepen as we are entering the winter energy crisis.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: Well, I think this is premature because this intervention in the energy markets will be rolled back with a lot of difficulty.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: The European Union worked for decades to liberalise energy markets and in just six months a lot of these gains have been basically abolished.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: Since October last year, when Russia began to play with gas supplies, government intervention into markets is increased in an attempt to control energy prices.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: But results have been limited. Prices have stayed stubbornly high and governments are continuing to subsidize and intervene. According to one research analyst, this needs to be handled very carefully.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: We saw governments step into markets and significantly subsidise both households to consume energy and industries to consume energy for the production of products.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: At the time, this was supposed to be a temporary measure to get through the winter and then we would shift back to business as usual.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: That hasn't been the case. Prices have clearly stayed high and governments are continuing to subsidise massively and intervene massively into energy markets on the prices side.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: And this is dangerous. This disrupts markets and ultimately pushes prices higher and higher because it enables consumers to keep consuming energy even when prices are at record high levels and pushes them higher and higher and higher.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: It's a sensitive issue for governments, but it makes sense to protect citizens and companies from rising prices. However, it's an unusual move to intervene within a liberal market that Europe has been building for over 20 years now.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: Krista Pichers, Euronews, Brussels.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: Saudi Arabia's Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman is in Paris for talks with French President Emmanuel Macron.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: The controversial meeting comes following renewed calls for a criminal investigation into bin Salman for his alleged involvement in the killing of Saudi journalist Jamal Khashoggi.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: As well as encouraging Saudi Arabia to increase oil production, a spokesperson for the French government says that Macron will raise human rights with the crown prince for more on this we turn to our international correspondent Annelies Borges in Paris when Saudi crown prince Mohammed bin Salman and France's president Emmanuel Macron sit down for dinner later today at the Elysee Palace this won't be the first time the two will be meeting since the killing of Saudi journalist Jamal Khashoggi back in 2018 in Istanbul.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: In fact, Emmanuel Macron was the very first Western leader to travel to Saudi Arabia after the incident back in December.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: Many NGOs and human rights groups today denounced the decision by France's president to host Mohammed bin Salman in such an intimate setting, saying that that was not necessary if he wanted to negotiate energy deals.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: Dialogue doesn't mean complacency, according to Emmanuel Macron's entourage that insists that negotiating with the world's biggest crude oil producer is necessary in the midst of one of Europe's biggest energy crises.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: Annelies Borges in Paris for Euronews.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: Coming up, what's a day marked every year, but increasingly always earlier and earlier.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: We're talking Earth Overshoot Day next, the date on which humanity has consumed all the resources the Earth can sustainably produce in one year.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: That's after the break.
